verses.latin: Paulus, vocatus Apostolus Iesu Christi per voluntatem Dei, et Sosthenes frater,
verses.english: Paul, called to be an Apostle of Jesus Christ by God's will, and Sosthenes the brother,

verses.latin: ecclesiae Dei, quae est Corinthi, sanctificatis in Christo Iesu, vocatis sanctis, cum omnibus qui invocant nomen Domini nostri Iesu Christi in omni loco ipsorum et nostro.
verses.english: to the Church of God in Corinth: to those who are consecrated to Christ Jesus, called to be holy, and to all those who call upon the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, in every place, their place and ours:

verses.latin: Gratia vobis, et pax a Deo Patre nostro, et Domino Iesu Christo.
verses.english: Grace to you, and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.latin: Gratias ago Deo meo semper pro vobis in gratia Dei, quae data est vobis in Christo Iesu:
verses.english: I give thanks to my God always concerning you, for the grace of God which has been given to you in Christ Jesus:

verses.latin: quod in omnibus divites facti estis in illo, in omni verbo et in omni scientia.
verses.english: that in everything you have been enriched in Him, in all speech and in all knowledge;

verses.latin: Sicut testimonium Christi confirmatum est in vobis:
verses.english: just as the testimony of Christ has been confirmed in you:

verses.latin: ita ut nihil vobis desit in ulla gratia, exspectantibus revelationem Domini nostri Iesu Christi.
verses.english: so that you are not lacking in any grace, awaiting the revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.latin: Qui et confirmabit vos usque in finem sine crimine in die adventus Domini nostri Iesu Christi.
verses.english: He will also strengthen you until the end, blameless in the day of the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.latin: Fidelis Deus: per quem vocati estis in societatem Filii eius Iesu Christi Domini nostri.
verses.english: God is faithful, by whom you were called into the fellowship of His Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.

verses.latin: Obsecro autem vos fratres, per nomen Domini nostri Iesu Christi, ut idipsum dicatis omnes, et non sint in vobis schismata: sitis autem perfecti in eodem sensu, et in eadem sententia.
verses.english: Now I beseech you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you all speak the same thing, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be perfectly united in the same mind and in the same judgment.

verses.latin: Significatum est enim mihi de vobis fratres mei a Chloe, quia contentiones sunt inter vos.
verses.english: For it has been signified to me concerning you, my brothers, by those of Chloe, that there are contentions among you.

verses.latin: Hoc autem dico, quod unusquisque vestrum dicit: Ego quidem sum Pauli: ego autem Apollo: ego vero Cephae: ego autem Christi.
verses.english: Now this I say, that each of you says: "I am of Paul," and "I am of Apollos," and "I am of Cephas," and "I am of Christ."

verses.latin: Divisus est Christus? Numquid Paulus crucifixus est pro vobis? aut in nomine Pauli baptizati estis?
verses.english: Is Christ divided? Was Paul crucified for you? Or were you baptized in the name of Paul?

verses.latin: Gratias ago Deo, quod neminem vestrum baptizavi, nisi Crispum et Gaium:
verses.english: I thank God that I baptized none of you, except Crispus and Gaius,

verses.latin: ne quis dicat quod in meo nomine baptizati estis.
verses.english: lest anyone should say that you were baptized in my name.

verses.latin: Baptizavi autem et Stephanæ domum: ceterum nescio si quem alium baptizaverim.
verses.english: And I also baptized the household of Stephanas. Besides, I do not know whether I baptized any other.

verses.latin: Non enim misit me Christus baptizare, sed evangelizare: non in sapientia verbi, ut non evacuetur crux Christi.
verses.english: For Christ did not send me to baptize, but to preach the Gospel: not with wisdom of speech, lest the cross of Christ should be emptied.

verses.latin: Verbum enim crucis pereuntibus quidem stultitia est: his autem qui salvantur, id est, nobis, Dei virtus est.
verses.english: For the word of the cross, to those who are perishing, is foolishness; but to us who are being saved, it is the power of God.

verses.latin: Scriptum est enim: Perdam sapientiam sapientium, et prudentiam prudentium reprobabo.
verses.english: For it is written: "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise, and I will reject the prudence of the prudent."

verses.latin: Ubi sapiens? Ubi scriba? Ubi conquisitor huius saeculi? Nonne stultam fecit Deus sapientiam huius mundi?
verses.english: Where is the wise man? Where is the scribe? Where is the debater of this age? Has not God made foolish the wisdom of this world?

verses.latin: Nam quia in Dei sapientia non cognovit mundus per sapientiam Deum, placuit Deo per stultitiam praedicationis salvos facere credentes.
verses.english: For since, in God's wisdom, the world did not know God through wisdom, God was pleased to save those who believe through the foolishness of preaching.

verses.latin: Quoniam et Iudaei signa petunt, et Graeci sapientiam quaerunt:
verses.english: For indeed, the Jews seek signs, and the Greeks seek wisdom:

verses.latin: nos autem praedicamus Christum crucifixum: Iudaeis quidem scandalum, gentibus autem stultitiam,
verses.english: but we preach Christ crucified, to the Jews indeed a stumbling block, and to the Gentiles foolishness,

verses.latin: ipsis autem vocatis Iudaeis, et Graecis, Christum Dei virtutem, et Dei sapientiam:
verses.english: but to those who are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God and the wisdom of God.

verses.latin: quia quod stultum est Dei, sapientius est hominibus: et quod infirmum est Dei, fortius est hominibus.
verses.english: Because that which is foolish of God is wiser than men, and that which is weak of God is stronger than men.

verses.latin: Videte enim vocationem vestram, fratres, quia non multi sapientes secundum carnem, non multi potentes, non multi nobiles:
verses.english: For consider your calling, brothers, that there were not many wise according to the flesh, not many powerful, not many noble:

verses.latin: sed quae stulta sunt mundi elegit Deus, ut confundat sapientes: et infirma mundi elegit Deus, ut confundat fortia:
verses.english: but God chose the foolish things of the world to confound the wise; and God chose the weak things of the world to confound the strong:

verses.latin: et ignobilia mundi, et contemta elegit Deus, et ea quae non sunt, ut ea quae sunt destrueret:
verses.english: and the base things of the world and the things that are despised God has chosen, and those things that are not, to bring to nothing those things that are:

verses.latin: ut non glorietur omnis caro in conspectu eius.
verses.english: so that no flesh should glory in His sight.

verses.latin: Ex ipso autem vos estis in Christo Iesu, qui factus est nobis sapientia a Deo, et iustitia, et sanctificatio, et redemptio:
verses.english: But of Him, you are in Christ Jesus, Who has been made our wisdom from God, and justice, and sanctification, and redemption:

verses.latin: ut quemadmodum scriptum est: Qui gloriatur, in Domino glorietur.
verses.english: so that, as it is written: "Let him who glories, glory in the Lord."

verses.latin: Et ego, cum venissem ad vos, fratres, veni non in sublimitate sermonis aut sapientiæ, annuntians vobis testimonium Christi.
verses.english: And when I came to you, brothers, I didn't come with fancy words or human wisdom, when I told you about the testimony of Christ.

verses.latin: Non enim judicavi me scire aliquid inter vos, nisi Jesum Christum, et hunc crucifixum.
verses.english: For I decided that I would know nothing among you except Jesus Christ, and Him crucified.

verses.latin: Et ego in infirmitate et timore, et tremore multo fui apud vos:
verses.english: And I was with you in weakness, and in fear, and in great trembling.

verses.latin: et sermo meus et prædicatio mea non in persuasibilibus humanæ sapientiæ verbis, sed in ostensione spiritus et virtutis:
verses.english: And my speech and my preaching were not in persuasive words of human wisdom, but in the demonstration of the Spirit and of power:

verses.latin: ut fides vestra non sit in sapientia hominum, sed in virtute Dei.
verses.english: so that your faith might not be in the wisdom of men, but in the power of God.

verses.latin: Sapientiam autem loquimur inter perfectos: sapientiam vero non hujus sæculi, neque principum hujus sæculi, qui destruuntur:
verses.english: However, we speak wisdom among those who are spiritually mature: but the wisdom of this world, nor of the rulers of this world, who are being destroyed,

verses.latin: sed loquimur Dei sapientiam in mysterio, quæ abscondita est, quam prædestinavit Deus ante sæcula in gloriam nostram:
verses.english: but we speak the wisdom of God in a mystery, which has been hidden, which God foreordained before the ages for our glory:

verses.latin: quam nemo ignoravit de principibus hujus sæculi: si enim cognovissent, numquam Dominum gloriæ crucifixissent.
verses.english: which none of the rulers of this age knew; for if they had known, they would never have crucified the Lord of glory.

verses.latin: Sed sicut scriptum est: Quod oculus non vidit, nec auris audivit, nec in cor hominis ascendit, quæ præparavit Deus iis qui diligunt illum.
verses.english: But as it is written, “What the eye has not seen, nor ear heard, nor the heart of man conceived, what God has prepared for those who love him.”

verses.latin: Nobis autem revelavit Deus per Spiritum suum: Spiritus enim omnia scrutatur, etiam profunda Dei.
verses.english: But God has revealed to us through His Spirit. For the Spirit searches everything, even the depths of God.

verses.latin: Quis enim hominum scit quæ sunt hominis, nisi spiritus hominis qui in ipso est? Ita et quæ Dei sunt, nemo novit, nisi Spiritus Dei.
verses.english: For who of men knows what is in a man, except the spirit of a man that is in him? So also the things of God no one knows, except the Spirit of God.

verses.latin: Nos autem non spiritum mundi accepimus, sed Spiritum qui ex Deo est: ut sciamus quæ a Deo donata sunt nobis:
verses.english: Now we have received not the spirit of the world, but the Spirit who is from God, that we might know the things freely given to us by God:

verses.latin: quæ et loquimur, non in doctis humanæ sapientiæ verbis, sed in doctrina Spiritus, spiritualibus spiritalibus conparantes.
verses.english: And we speak these things, not in words taught by human wisdom, but in those taught by the Spirit, comparing spiritual things with spiritual ones.

verses.latin: Animalis autem homo non percipit ea quæ sunt Spiritus Dei: stultitia enim est illi: et non potest intellegere, quia spiritualiter examinatur.
verses.english: The natural man does not receive the things of the Spirit of God, for they are foolishness to him: and he cannot understand them, because they are spiritually discerned.

verses.latin: Spiritualis autem dijudicat omnia, et ipse a nemine judicatur.
verses.english: But he that is spiritual judges all things; yet he himself is judged by no one.

verses.latin: Quis enim cognovit sensum Domini, qui instruat eum? Nos autem sensum Christi habemus.
verses.english: For who has known the mind of the Lord, that he may instruct him? But we have the mind of Christ.

verses.latin: Et ego, fratres, non potui vobis loqui quasi spiritualibus, sed quasi carnalibus. Tamquam parvulis in Christo.
verses.english: And I, brothers, couldn’t speak to you as to spiritual people, but as to those of the flesh, as to babies in Christ.

verses.latin: Lac vobis potum dedi, non escam: nondum enim poteratis: sed neque adhuc potestis: nondum enim estis capaces.
verses.english: I gave you milk to drink, not solid food. You couldn’t yet digest the harder truths of the Gospel. And you still aren’t able, for you still aren’t capable of it.

verses.latin: Adhuc enim carnales estis. Nam cum sit inter vos zelus, et contentio: nonne carnales estis, et secundum homines ambulatis?
verses.english: For you are still carnal. For since there is jealousy and fighting among you, aren’t you carnal, and do you walk according to worldly standards?

verses.latin: Cum enim dicit aliquis: Ego quidem sum Pauli: alius autem: Ego Apollo: nonne homines estis?
verses.english: For when one says, “I am of Paul,” and another, “I am of Apollos,” aren’t you merely men?

verses.latin: Quis igitur est Paulus? Quis est Apollo? Ministri per quos credidistis, et unicuique sicut Dominus dedit.
verses.english: So what then is Paul? And what is Apollos? They are ministers through whom you believed, and to each one as the Lord gave to him.

verses.latin: Ego plantavi, Apollo rigavit: sed Deus incrementum dedit.
verses.english: I planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the increase.

verses.latin: Itaque neque qui plantat est aliquid, neque qui rigat: sed qui incrementum dat, Deus.
verses.english: So neither the one who plants is anything, nor the one who waters, but God, who gives the increase.

verses.latin: Qui plantat autem, et qui rigat, unum sunt. Unusquisque autem propriam mercedem accipiet secundum suum laborem.
verses.english: Now he who plants and he who waters are one, and each one will receive his own reward according to his own work.

verses.latin: Dei enim adjutores sumus: Dei agricultura estis, Dei aedificatio estis.
verses.english: For we are fellow workers with God. You are God's field, you are God's building.

verses.latin: Secundum gratiam Dei, quae data est mihi, ut sapiens architectus fundamentum posui: alius autem superædificat. Unusquisque autem videat quomodo superædificet.
verses.english: According to the grace of God given to me, as a wise architect, I have laid the foundation, and another builds on it. But let each one take heed how he builds on it.

verses.latin: Fundamentum enim aliud nemo potest ponere, praeter id quod positum est: quod est Christus Jesus.
verses.english: For no one can lay any other foundation besides that which is laid, which is Christ Jesus.

verses.latin: Si quis autem superædificat in fundamento hoc, aurum, argentum, lapides pretiosos, ligna, fenum, stipulam,
verses.english: Now if anyone builds on this foundation with gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, straw,

verses.latin: uniuscujusque opus manifestum erit: dies enim Domini declarabit: quia in igne revelabitur. Uniuscujusque opus quale sit, ignis probabit.
verses.english: the work of each one will be revealed. For the Day of the Lord will declare it, because it will be revealed in fire, and the fire will test what sort of work each one has built.

verses.latin: Si cujus opus manserit quod superædificavit, mercedem accipiet.
verses.english: If anyone's work remains which he has built on, he will receive a reward.

verses.latin: Si cujus opus arserit, damnum patietur: ipse autem salvus erit, sic tamen quasi per ignem.
verses.english: If anyone's work is burned up, he will suffer loss, but he himself will be saved, yet so as through fire.

verses.latin: Nescitis quia templum Dei estis, et Spiritus Dei habitat in vobis?
verses.english: Don’t you know that you are the temple of God, and that the Spirit of God dwells in you?

verses.latin: Si quis templum Dei violaverit, perdet illum Deus. Templum enim Dei sanctum est, quod estis vos.
verses.english: If anyone defiles the temple of God, God will destroy him. For the temple of God is holy, and you are that temple.

verses.latin: Nemo se seducat: si quis videtur inter vos sapiens esse in hoc saeculo, stultus fiat ut sit sapiens.
verses.english: Let no one deceive himself. If anyone among you seems to be wise in this world, let him become a fool so that he may be wise.

verses.latin: Sapientia enim hujus mundi stultitia est apud Deum. Scriptum est enim: Qui apprehendit sapientes in astutia eorum.
verses.english: For the wisdom of this world is foolishness to God. For it is written, “He catches the wise in their craftiness.”

verses.latin: Et iterum: Dominus novit cogitationes sapientium quoniam vanae sunt.
verses.english: And again, “The Lord knows the thoughts of the wise, that they are vain.”

verses.latin: Itaque nemo glorietur in hominibus. Omnia enim vestra sunt:
verses.english: Therefore, let no one boast in men. For all things are yours:

verses.latin: sive Paulus, sive Apollo, sive Cephas, sive mundus, sive vita, sive mors, sive praesentia, sive futura: omnia enim vestra sunt:
verses.english: whether Paul or Apollos or Cephas, or the world or life or death, or the present or the future—all are yours,

verses.latin: vos autem Christi: Christus autem Dei.
verses.english: and you are Christ’s, and Christ is God’s.

verses.latin: Sic nos existimet homo ut ministros Christi, et dispensatores mysteriorum Dei.
verses.english: Everyone should regard us as emissaries of Christ and stewards of God’s mysteries.

verses.latin: Iam de cetero requiritur in dispensatoribus ut fidelis quis inveniatur.
verses.english: Furthermore, it is required of stewards that they be found faithful.

verses.latin: Mihi autem pro minimo est ut a vobis iudicer, aut ab humano die: sed neque meipsum iudico.
verses.english: It matters very little to me if I’m judged by you or by any human court. I don’t even judge myself.

verses.latin: Nihil enim mihi conscius sum, sed non in hoc justificatus sum: qui autem iudicat me, Dominus est.
verses.english: I’m not aware of anything I’ve done wrong, but that doesn’t mean I’m right. The Lord is the one who will judge me.

verses.latin: Itaque nolite ante tempus judicare, quoadusque veniat Dominus: qui et illuminabit abscondita tenebrarum, et manifestabit consilia cordium: et tunc laus erit unicuique a Deo.
verses.english: So don’t make judgments before the Lord comes. He will bring to light what is hidden in darkness and will reveal the motives of the heart. Then each person will receive their praise from God.

verses.latin: Haec autem, fratres, translata sum in me et Apollo propter vos: ut in nobis discatis, ne supra quam scriptum est, sapere, ut non inflati sitis pro altero adversus alterum.
verses.english: Now, brothers and sisters, I have applied these things to myself and Apollos for your benefit, so that you may learn through us not to go beyond what is written, so that none of you will be puffed up in favor of one against the other.

verses.latin: Quis enim te discernit? Quid autem habes quod non accepisti? Si autem accepisti, quid gloriaris quasi non acceperis?
verses.english: For who makes you different from others? What do you have that you did not receive? And if you did receive it, why do you boast as though you did not?

verses.latin: Iam saturati estis, iam divites facti estis: sine nobis regnatis: et utinam regnaretis ut et nos vobiscum regnaremus.
verses.english: Already you have all you want! Already you have become rich! You have become kings—and that without us! How I wish that you really had become kings, so that we also might rule with you!

verses.latin: Puto enim quod Deus nos apostolos novissimos ostendit, tamquam morti destinatos: quia spectaculum facti sumus mundo, et angelis, et hominibus.
verses.english: For it seems to me that God has exhibited us apostles as last of all, as men condemned to death, because we have become a spectacle to the world, both to angels and to men.

verses.latin: Nos stulti propter Christum, vos autem prudentes in Christo: nos infirmi, vos autem fortes: vos nobiles, nos autem ignobiles.
verses.english: We are fools for Christ’s sake, but you are so wise in Christ! We are weak, but you are strong! You are honored, we are dishonored!

verses.latin: Usque in hanc horam et esurimus, et sitimus, et nudi sumus, et colaphis caedimur, et instabiles sumus,
verses.english: To this very hour we go hungry and thirsty, we are poorly clothed, roughly treated, and homeless.

verses.latin: et laboramus operantes manibus nostris: maledicti benedicimus: persecutionem patimur, et sustinemus:
verses.english: We work hard with our own hands. When we are cursed, we bless; when we are persecuted, we endure it;

verses.latin: blasphemamur, et obsecramus: tamquam purgamenta hujus mundi facti sumus, omnium peripsema usque adhuc.
verses.english: when we are slandered, we answer kindly. We have become the scum of the earth, the garbage of the world—right up to this moment.

verses.latin: Non ut confundam vos, haec scribo, sed ut filios meos carissimos moneo.
verses.english: I am not writing this to shame you, but to warn you as my dear children.

verses.latin: Nam si decem millia paedagogorum habeatis in Christo, sed non multos patres. Nam in Christo Jesu per Evangelium ego vos genui.
verses.english: For even if you had ten thousand guardians in Christ, you do not have many fathers, for in Christ Jesus I became your father through the gospel.

verses.latin: Rogo ergo vos, imitatores mei estote.
verses.english: Therefore I urge you to imitate me.

verses.latin: Ideo misi ad vos Timotheum, qui est filius meus carissimus et fidelis in Domino: qui vos commonefaciet vias meas, quae sunt in Christo Jesu: sicut ubique in omni ecclesia doceo.
verses.english: For this reason I am sending to you Timothy, my son whom I love, who is faithful in the Lord. He will remind you of my way of life in Christ Jesus, as I teach it everywhere in every church.

verses.latin: Tamquam non venturus sim ad vos, inflati sunt quidam.
verses.english: Some of you have become arrogant, as though I were not coming to you.

verses.latin: Veniam autem cito ad vos, si voluerit Dominus: et cognoscam non sermonem eorum qui inflati sunt, sed virtutem.
verses.english: But I will come to you very soon, if the Lord is willing, and then I will find out not only what these arrogant people say, but also what power they have.

verses.latin: Non enim in sermone, sed in virtute est regnum Dei.
verses.english: For the kingdom of God is not a matter of talk, but of power.

verses.latin: Quid vultis? in virga veniam ad vos, an in charitate, et spiritu mansuetudinis?
verses.english: What do you prefer? Shall I come to you with a rod, or shall I come with love and with a gentle spirit?

verses.latin: In toto auditur fornicatio inter vos, et talis fornicatio, qualis nec inter gentes, ita ut uxorem patris sui aliquis habeat.
verses.english: It is reported that there is unchastity among you, and such unchastity as is not even among the Gentiles, so that a man has his father's wife.

verses.latin: Et vos inflati estis: et non magis luctum habuistis, ut tolleretur de medio vestrum qui hoc opus fecit?
verses.english: And you are puffed up, and have not rather mourned, that he who has done this deed might be taken away from among you?

verses.latin: Ego quidem absens corpore, praesens autem spiritu, jam judicavi ut praesens eum qui ita operatus est,
verses.english: I indeed, being absent in body, but present in spirit, have already judged, as though I were present, him who has so done,

verses.latin: in nomine Domini nostri Jesu Christi, congregatis vobis et spiritu meo, cum virtute Domini nostri Jesu,
verses.english: In the name of Our Lord Jesus Christ, when you are gathered together, and my spirit, with the power of Our Lord Jesus,

verses.latin: tradere hujusmodi hominem Satanæ in interitum carnis, ut spiritus salvus sit in die Domini Jesu.
verses.english: To deliver such a one to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved in the day of Our Lord Jesus.

verses.latin: Non est bona gloriatio vestra. Nescitis quia modicum fermentum totam massam corrumpit?
verses.english: Your boasting is not good. Do you not know that a little leaven corrupts the whole lump?

verses.latin: Expurgate vetus fermentum, ut sitis nova conspersio, sicut estis azymi. Etenim Pascha nostrum immolatus est Christus.
verses.english: Purge out the old leaven, that you may be a new paste, as you are unleavened. For Christ our Passover is sacrificed.

verses.latin: Itaque epulemur, non in fermento veteri, neque in fermento malitiæ et nequitiæ, sed in azymis sinceritatis et veritatis.
verses.english: Therefore, let us feast, not with the old leaven, nor with the leaven of malice and wickedness, but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.

verses.latin: Scripsi vobis in epistola: Non commisceamini fornicariis:
verses.english: I wrote to you in an epistle: Not to keep company with fornicators.

verses.latin: non utique fornicariis hujus mundi, aut avaris, aut rapacibus, aut idolis servientibus: alioquin debuistis de mundo exisse.
verses.english: I meant not with the fornicators of this world, or with the covetous, or the extortioners, or the idolaters; otherwise you must have gone out of this world.

verses.latin: Nunc autem scripsi vobis non commisceamini: si is qui frater nominatur, fornicator est, aut avarus, aut idolis serviens, aut maledicus, aut ebriosus, aut rapax, cum ejusmodi nec cibum sumere.
verses.english: But now I have written to you not to keep company, if any man that is named a brother, be a fornicator, or covetous, or a server of idols, or a railer, or a drunkard, or an extortioner: with such a one do not eat.

verses.latin: Quid enim mihi de iis qui foris sunt, judicare? Nonne de iis qui intus sunt, vos judicatis?
verses.english: For what have I to do to judge them that are without? Do you not judge them that are within?

verses.latin: Nam eos qui foris sunt, Deus judicabit. Auferte malum ex vobisipsis.
verses.english: For them that are without, God will judge. Put away the evil one from among yourselves.

verses.latin: Audet aliquis vestrum, habens negotium adversus alterum, judicari apud iniquos, et non apud sanctos?
verses.english: Does anyone among you, who has a case against another, dare to go to court before the unbelievers, and not before the saints?

verses.latin: An nescitis quoniam sancti de mundo judicabunt? Et si in vobis judicabitur mundus, indigni estis qui de minimis judicetis?
verses.english: Do you not know that the saints will judge the world? And if the world is to be judged by you, are you unworthy to judge the smallest matters?

verses.latin: Nescitis quoniam angelos judicabimus? quanto magis saecularia?
verses.english: Do you not know that we will judge angels? How much more things of this world?

verses.latin: Saeu-cularia igitur judicia si habueritis, eos qui contemptibiles sunt in Ecclesia, hos constituite ad judicandum.
verses.english: So if you have worldly judgements, then appoint those who are least esteemed in the Church to judge these matters.

verses.latin: Ad confusionem vestram dico. Sic non est in vobis sapiens quisquam qui possit judicare inter fratrem et fratrem?
verses.english: I speak this to your shame. Is there not a wise man among you who can judge between his brother and his brother?

verses.latin: Sed frater cum fratre judicatur, et hoc apud infideles.
verses.english: But brother goes to court against brother, and that before unbelievers.

verses.latin: Iam quidem omnino defectio est in vobis, quod judicia habetis inter vos. Quare non magis injuriam accipitis? quare non magis fraudem patimini?
verses.english: Now indeed there is utter failure among you, because you have lawsuits with one another. Why do you not rather suffer wrong? Why do you not rather be defrauded?

verses.latin: Sed vos injuriam facitis, et fraudatis: et hoc fratribus.
verses.english: But you yourselves do wrong and defraud, and that among your brothers.

verses.latin: An nescitis quia iniqui regnum Dei non possidebunt? Nolite errare: neque fornicarii, neque idolis servientes, neque adulteri,
verses.english: Do you not know that the unjust will not possess the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived: neither fornicators, nor idolaters, nor adulterers,

verses.latin: neque molles, neque masculorum concubitores, neque fures, neque avari, neque ebriosi, neque maledici, neque rapaces, regnum Dei possidebunt.
verses.english: nor the effeminate, nor those who practice homosexuality, nor thieves, nor the greedy, nor drunkards, nor revilers, nor extortioners will possess the kingdom of God.

verses.latin: Et haec fuistis aliqui: sed abluti estis, sed sanctificati estis, sed justificati estis in nomine Domini Jesu Christi, et in Spiritu Dei nostri.
verses.english: And such were some of you, but you were washed, you were sanctified, you were justified in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ, and in the Spirit of our God.

verses.latin: Omnia mihi licent, sed non omnia expediunt: omnia mihi licent, sed ego sub nullius potestate adducar.
verses.english: All things are lawful for me, but not all things are helpful. All things are lawful for me, but I will not be brought under the power of anything.

verses.latin: Victualia ventri, et venter victualiis: Deus autem et hunc et haec destruet. Corpus autem non fornicationi, sed Domino: et Dominus corpori.
verses.english: Food is for the stomach, and the stomach is for food, but God will destroy both it and them. But the body is not for fornication, but for the Lord, and the Lord for the body.

verses.latin: Deus vero et Dominum suscitavit, et nos suscitabit per virtutem suam.
verses.english: And God raised up the Lord, and He will also raise us up by His power.

verses.latin: Nescitis quoniam corpora vestra membra sunt Christi? Tollens igitur membra Christi, faciam ea membra meretricis? Absit.
verses.english: Do you not know that your bodies are members of Christ? Shall I then take the members of Christ, and make them members of a harlot? God forbid.

verses.latin: An nescitis quoniam qui jungitur meretrici, unum corpus est? Erunt enim, inquit, duo in carne una.
verses.english: Do you not know that he who is joined to a harlot is one body with her? For “the two,” He says, “shall be one flesh.”

verses.latin: Qui autem adhaeret Deo, unus spiritus est.
verses.english: But he who is joined to God is one spirit with Him.

verses.latin: Fugite fornicationem. Omne peccatum quodcumque fecerit homo, extra corpus est: qui autem fornicatur, in corpus suum peccat.
verses.english: Flee from fornication. Every sin that a man does is outside the body, but he who commits fornication sins against his own body.

verses.latin: An nescitis quoniam corpus vestrum templum est Spiritus Sancti, qui in vobis est, quem habetis a Deo, et non estis vestri?
verses.english: Do you not know that your body is the temple of the Holy Spirit, who is within you, whom you have from God, and that you are not your own?

verses.latin: Empti enim estis pretio magno. Glorificate et portate Deum in corpore vestro.
verses.english: For you were bought at a great price. Therefore glorify God in your body.

verses.latin: De his autem quae scripsistis mihi, bonum est homini mulierem non tangere.
verses.english: Concerning the things you wrote to me: It is good for a man not to touch a woman, which means not to engage in sexual relations.

verses.latin: Propter fornicationem autem unusquisque suam uxorem habeat, et unaquaeque suum virum habeat.
verses.english: But in order to avoid the temptation of fornication, let each man have his own wife, and let each woman have her own husband.

verses.latin: Uxori vir debitum reddat: similiter autem et uxor viro.
verses.english: Let the husband give to the wife what is owed to her; and in the same way, let the wife give what is owed to the husband.

verses.latin: Mulier sui corporis potestatem non habet, sed vir: similiter autem et vir sui corporis potestatem non habet, sed mulier.
verses.english: The wife does not have power over her own body, but the husband does. Likewise, the husband does not have power over his own body, but the wife does.

verses.latin: Nolite fraudare invicem, nisi forte ex consensu ad tempus, ut vacetis orationi: et iterum revertimini in idipsum, ne tentet vos Satanas propter incontinentiam vestram.
verses.english: Do not defraud one another, except perhaps by consent for a time, so that you may give yourselves to prayer. Return to each other, so that Satan does not tempt you because of your lack of self-control.

verses.latin: Dico autem hoc secundum indulgentiam, non secundum imperium.
verses.english: Now I say this as a concession, not as a command.

verses.latin: Volo enim omnes homines esse sicut me ipsum: sed unusquisque proprium donum habet ex Deo: alius quidem sic, alius autem sic.
verses.english: For I wish that all men were like myself. But each one has his own gift from God: one in this way, and another in that.

verses.latin: Dico autem non nuptis et viduis: bonum est illis si sic maneant, sicut et ego.
verses.english: But I say to the unmarried and to the widows that it is good for them if they remain as I do.

verses.latin: Quod si non se continent, nubant. Melius est enim nubere quam uri.
verses.english: But if they do not have self-control, let them marry. For it is better to marry than to be aflame with passion.

verses.latin: His autem qui matrimonio juncti sunt, praecipio, non ego, sed Dominus: uxorem a viro non discedere.
verses.english: But to those who are joined in marriage, I command—not I, but the Lord: that a wife should not depart from her husband.

verses.latin: Quod si discesserit, maneat innupta, aut viro suo reconcilietur. Et vir uxorem non dimittat.
verses.english: But if she departs, let her remain unmarried or be reconciled to her husband. And let not the husband divorce his wife.

verses.latin: Nam ceteris ego dico, non Dominus: si quis frater uxorem habet infidelem, et haec consentit habitare cum illo, non dimittat illam.
verses.english: To the rest I say—not the Lord—that if any brother has a wife who is an unbeliever, and she consents to live with him, let him not divorce her.

verses.latin: Et si qua mulier habet virum infidelem, et hic consentit habitare cum illa, non dimittat virum.
verses.english: And if any woman has a husband who is an unbeliever, and he consents to live with her, let her not divorce the husband.

verses.latin: Sanctificatus est enim vir infidelis per mulierem fidelem: et sanctificata est mulier infidelis per virum fidelem: alioquin filii vestri immundi essent, nunc autem sancti sunt.
verses.english: For the unbelieving husband is sanctified by the believing wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the believing husband. Otherwise, your children would be unclean, but now they are holy.

verses.latin: Quod si infidelis discedit, discedat. Non enim servituti subjectus est frater aut soror in talibus: in pace autem vocavit nos Deus.
verses.english: But if the unbeliever departs, let him depart. For a brother or sister is not subject to servitude in such cases. But God has called us to peace.

verses.latin: Quid enim scis, mulier, si virum salvum facies? aut quid scis, vir, si mulierem salvam facies?
verses.english: For how do you know, woman, whether you will save your husband? Or how do you know, man, whether you will save your wife?

verses.latin: Nisi unicuique sicut divisit Deus, unumquemque sicut vocavit Dominus, ita ambulet: et sicut in omnibus ecclesiis doceo.
verses.english: But as God has allotted to each one, as the Lord has called each one, so let him walk. And this is what I teach in all the churches.

verses.latin: Circumcisus aliquis vocatus est? non praecidatur. In praeputio aliquis vocatus est? non circumcidatur.
verses.english: Was anyone called while circumcised? Let him not seek to reverse it. Was anyone called while uncircumcised? Let him not be circumcised.

verses.latin: Circumcisio nihil est, et praeputium nihil est: sed observatio mandatorum Dei.
verses.english: Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing, but the keeping of the commandments of God is what matters.

verses.latin: Unusquisque in qua vocatione vocatus est, in ea permaneat.
verses.english: Let each one remain in the calling in which he was called.

verses.latin: Servus vocatus es? non sit tibi curae: sed et si potes liber fieri, magis utere.
verses.english: Were you called as a slave? Do not worry about it. But if you can become free, avail yourself of the opportunity.

verses.latin: Qui enim in Domino vocatus est servus,liber est Domini: similiter qui liber vocatus est, servus est Christi.
verses.english: For the one who was called in the Lord as a slave is a freedman of the Lord; likewise, the one who was called as a free man is a slave of Christ.

verses.latin: Caro pretio empta est: nolite fieri servientes hominum.
verses.english: You were bought with a price; do not become slaves of men.

verses.latin: Unusquisque, in quo vocatus est, fratres, in eo permaneat coram Deo.
verses.english: So then, brothers, in whatever state each was called, there let him remain with God.

verses.latin: De virginibus autem praeceptum Domini non habeo: consilium autem do, tamquam misericordiam consecutus a Domino, ut sim fidelis.
verses.english: Now concerning virgins, I have no command from the Lord, but I give an opinion, as one who has received mercy from the Lord to be trustworthy.

verses.latin: Existimo ergo hoc bonum esse propter instantem necessitatem, quoniam bonum est homini sic esse.
verses.english: I think then that this is good on account of the present distress, that it is good for a man to be as he is.

verses.latin: Alligatus es uxori? noli quaerere solutionem. Solutus es ab uxore? noli quaerere uxorem.
verses.english: Are you bound to a wife? Do not seek release. Are you free from a wife? Do not seek a wife.

verses.latin: Si autem acceperis uxorem, non peccasti: et si nupserit virgo, non peccavit: tribulationem tamen carnis habebunt hujusmodi. Ego autem vos parco.
verses.english: But if you marry, you have not sinned. And if a virgin marries, she has not sinned. Yet such people will have trouble in the flesh, and I am trying to spare you.

verses.latin: Hoc autem dico, fratres: tempus breve est: reliquum est ut et qui habent uxores, tamquam non habentes sint:
verses.english: But this I say, brothers: the time is short. From now on, let those who have wives be as though they had none,

verses.latin: et qui flent, tamquam non flentes: et qui gaudent, tamquam non gaudentes: et qui emunt, tamquam non possidentes:
verses.english: and those who weep as though they were not weeping, and those who rejoice as though they were not rejoicing, and those who buy as though they did not possess,

verses.latin: et qui utuntur hoc mundo, tamquam non utantur: praeterit enim figura hujus mundi.
verses.english: and those who make use of the world as though they did not make full use of it, for the form of this world is passing away.

verses.latin: Volo autem vos sine sollicitudine esse. Qui sine uxore est, sollicitus est quae Domini sunt, quomodo placeat Deo.
verses.english: I want you to be free from anxieties. The unmarried man is anxious about the things of the Lord, how to please the Lord.

verses.latin: Qui autem cum uxore est, sollicitus est quae sunt mundi, quomodo placeat uxori.
verses.english: But the one who is married is anxious about the things of the world, how to please his wife.

verses.latin: Et divisus est. Mulier innupta, et virgo, cogitat quae Domini sunt, ut sit sancta et corpore et spiritu. Quae autem nupta est, cogitat quae sunt mundi, quomodo placeat viro.
verses.english: And there is a division. The unmarried woman, and the virgin, is anxious about the things of the Lord, so that she may be holy in both body and spirit. But the one who is married is anxious about the things of the world, how to please her husband.

verses.latin: Porro hoc ad utilitatem vestram dico: non ut laqueum vobis injiciam, sed ad id quod honestum est, et quod facultatem praebeat sine impedimento Domino, inservire.
verses.english: I am saying this for your own benefit, not to put a restraint upon you, but to promote what is proper and to secure your undivided devotion to the Lord.

verses.latin: Si quis autem turpem se videt agere super virginem suam, si forte fuerit superpubes, et ita oportet fieri: quod vult faciat: non peccat: nubant.
verses.english: If anyone thinks that he is not behaving properly toward his virgin, if she is past her youth, and if it must be so, let him do as he wishes; he does not sin; let them marry.

verses.latin: Nam qui statuit in corde suo firmus, non habens necessitatem, potestatem autem habens suae voluntatis, et hoc judicavit in corde suo, servare virginem suam, bene facit.
verses.english: But he who stands firm in his heart, being under no necessity, but having control over his own will, and has determined in his heart to keep his virgin, does well.

verses.latin: Igitur et qui matrimonio jungit virginem suam, bene facit: et qui non jungit, melius facit.
verses.english: So then, he who gives his virgin in marriage does well, and he who does not give her in marriage does better.

verses.latin: Mulier alligata est legi quanto tempore vir ejus vivit: quod si dormierit vir ejus, liberata est: cui vult nubat, tantum in Domino.
verses.english: A wife is bound by law for as long as her husband lives. But if her husband dies, she is free to marry whom she wishes, only in the Lord.

verses.latin: Beatior autem erit si sic manserit, secundum meam sententiam: puto autem quod et ego spiritum Dei habeam.
verses.english: But in my judgment, she is happier if she remains as she is. And I think that I also have the Spirit of God.

verses.latin: De his igitur quae idolothytis, scimus quod omnes scientiam habemus. Scientia inflat, caritas vero aedificat.
verses.english: Now about the things that have been sacrificed to idols: we know that we all have knowledge. Knowledge by itself causes pride, but charity builds up the Church.

verses.latin: Si quis autem se existimat scire aliquid, nondum cognovit quemadmodum oporteat scire.
verses.english: If anyone thinks he knows something, he doesn’t yet know it the way he should.

verses.latin: Si quis autem diligit Deum, hic cognitus est ab eo.
verses.english: But if anyone loves God, he is known by Him.

verses.latin: De manducatione igitur idolothytorum, scimus quod nihil est idolum in mundo, et quod nullus est Deus nisi unus.
verses.english: Concerning the eating of food offered to idols, we know that an idol is nothing in the world, and that there is no God except for the One God.

verses.latin: Nam etsi sunt qui dicantur dii, sive in caelo sive in terra (sicut sunt dii multi, et domini multi):
verses.english: Even if there are those who are called gods, whether in the sky or on the earth, as there are many gods and many lords:

verses.latin: nobis tamen unus Deus Pater, ex quo omnia, et nos in ipso: et unus Dominus Jesus Christus, per quem omnia, et nos per ipsum.
verses.english: For us, there is only one God the Father, from whom all things come and in whom we live; and one Lord Jesus Christ, through whom all things are, and through whom we live.

verses.latin: Sed non in omnibus est scientia. Quidam autem in conscientia idoli usque nunc manducant quasi idolothytum: et conscientia ipsorum infirma, contaminatur.
verses.english: But not everyone has this knowledge. Some, through their attachment to idols, eat food that has been sacrificed to idols, and because their conscience is weak, they are defiled.

verses.latin: Cibus autem nos non commendat Deo. Neque enim si manducaverimus, abundabimus: neque si non manducaverimus, deficiemus.
verses.english: Food does not recommend us to God. For if we eat, we are not better; and if we do not eat, we are not worse off.

verses.latin: Videte autem ne forte haec potestas vestra offendiculum fiat infirmis.
verses.english: But be careful that your freedom of conscience does not become an occasion of stumbling for the weak.

verses.latin: Si enim quis viderit eum qui habet scientiam, in idolo recumbentem, nonne conscientia ejus qui infirmus est, aedificabitur ad manducandum idolothyta?
verses.english: For if someone sees you who has knowledge eating in an idol’s temple, won’t the conscience of the weak man be emboldened to eat food sacrificed to idols?

verses.latin: Peribit enim infirmus in tua scientia, frater, propter quem Christus mortuus est.
verses.english: So by your knowledge, the weak brother will be destroyed, because Christ died for him.

verses.latin: Sic autem peccantes in fratres, et percutientes conscientiam eorum infirmam, in Christum peccatis.
verses.english: When you sin against your brothers and wound their weak conscience, you sin against Christ.

verses.latin: Quapropter, si esca scandalizat fratrem meum, non manducabo carnem in aeternum, ne fratrem meum scandalizem.
verses.english: Therefore, if food causes my brother to stumble, I will never eat meat again, lest I cause my brother to stumble.

verses.latin: Non sum ego Apostolus? non sum liber? nonne Iesum Christum Dominum nostrum vidi? nonne opus meum vos estis in Domino?
verses.english: Am I not an Apostle? Am I not free? Have I not seen Jesus Christ Our Lord? Are you not the fruit of my ministry in the Lord?

verses.latin: et si aliis non sum Apostolus, sed tamen vobis sum: nam signaculum apostolatus mei vos estis in Domino.
verses.english: Even if I am not an Apostle to others, I am certainly one to you. You are proof that I am an Apostle of the Lord.

verses.latin: Mea defensio illis qui me interrogant, haec est:
verses.english: To those who question me, this is my defense:

verses.latin: numquid non habemus potestatem manducandi et bibendi?
verses.english: Do we not have the right to eat and drink?

verses.latin: numquid non habemus potestatem mulierem sororem circumducendi, sicut et ceteri Apostoli, et fratres Domini, et Cephas?
verses.english: Do we not have the right to take a wife, a sister in the faith, as do the other Apostles, and the brothers of the Lord, and Cephas?

verses.latin: aut ego solus et Barnabas, non habemus potestatem hoc operandi?
verses.english: Or is it only Barnabas and I who do not have the right to stop working to support ourselves?

verses.latin: quis militat suis stipendiis umquam? quis plantat vineam, et de fructu eius non edit? aut quis pascit gregem, et de lacte gregis non manducat?
verses.english: Who serves as a soldier at his own expense? Who plants a vineyard and does not eat of its fruit? Or who tends a flock and does not eat of the milk of the flock?

verses.latin: Numquid secundum hominem haec dico? an et lex haec non dicit?
verses.english: Am I speaking merely as a man? Does not the Law also speak these things?

verses.latin: Scriptum est enim in lege Moysi: Non iunges os bovi trituranti. Numquid de bobus curat Deus?
verses.english: For it is written in the Law of Moses, “You shall not muzzle the ox that treads out the grain.” Is it for oxen that God is concerned?

verses.latin: an propter nos utique dicit? Nam propter nos scripta sunt: quoniam debet in spe qui arat, et qui triturant, in spe fructus percipiendi.
verses.english: Or does He speak entirely for our sake? Indeed, it was written for our sake, so that he who plows should plow in hope, and he who threshes should thresh in hope of receiving a share of the harvest.

verses.latin: Si vobis nos spiritualia seminavimus, magnum est si carnalia vestra metamus?
verses.english: If we have sown spiritual things for you, is it a great thing if we reap your material things?

verses.latin: Si alii potestatis vestrae participes fiunt, cur non potius nos? Sed non usi sumus hac potestate: sed omnia sustinemus, ne quod offendiculum demus evangelio Christi.
verses.english: If others share in your rights, why not even more so we? But we have not used this right. We endure anything rather than put an obstacle in the way of the gospel of Christ.

verses.latin: Nescitis quod qui in sacris operantur, quae de sacrificio sunt, edunt? et qui altari deserviunt, cum altari participant?
verses.english: Do you not know that those who are employed in the temple service get their food from the temple, and those who serve at the altar share in the offerings?

verses.latin: Ita et Dominus ordinavit his qui evangelium annuntiant, de evangelio vivere.
verses.english: In the same way, the Lord commanded that those who proclaim the gospel should live by the gospel.

verses.latin: Ego autem non sum usus istis. Neque haec scripsi ut ita fiant in me: bonum est enim mihi magis mori, quam ut gloriam meam nemo evacuet.
verses.english: But I have not used any of these rights, nor am I writing this in order that it may be done for me. For I would rather die than have anyone deprive me of my reason for boasting.

verses.latin: Nam si evangelizo, non est mihi gloria: necessitas enim mihi incumbit: vae enim mihi est, si non evangelizavero.
verses.english: For if I preach the gospel, I have no reason to boast, because an obligation is laid on me. Woe to me if I do not preach the gospel!

verses.latin: Si enim volens hoc ago, mercedem habeo: si autem invitus, dispensatio mihi credita est.
verses.english: For if I do this of my own will, I have a reward, but if I do it unwillingly, I am entrusted with a commission.

verses.latin: Quae est ergo merces mea? ut evangelizans gratis ponam evangelium Christi, ut non abutar potestate mea in evangelio.
verses.english: What then is my reward? That, in preaching the gospel, I may offer the gospel free of charge, so as not to make full use of my right in the gospel.

verses.latin: Nam cum liber essem ex omnibus, omnibus me servum feci, ut plures lucrifacerem.
verses.english: For though I am free from all, I have made myself a servant to all, that I might win more of them.

verses.latin: Et factus sum Iudaeis tamquam Iudaeus, ut Iudaeos lucrifacerem: his qui sub lege sunt, tamquam sub legem essem, cum ipse non essem sub lege: ut eos qui sub lege sunt, lucrifacerem.
verses.english: To the Jews I became as a Jew, that I might win Jews. To those under the law I became as one under the law (though not being myself under the law) that I might win those under the law.

verses.latin: His qui sine lege sunt, tamquam sine lege essem (non sine lege Dei, sed in lege Christi), ut lucrifacerem eos qui sine lege sunt.
verses.english: To those outside the law I became as one outside the law (not being without the law of God but under the law of Christ), that I might win those outside the law.

verses.latin: Factus sum infirmis infirmus, ut infirmos lucrifacerem. Omnibus omnia factus sum, ut omnes facerem salvos.
verses.english: To the weak I became weak, that I might win the weak. I have become all things to all men, that I might by all means save some.

verses.latin: hoc autem facio propter Evangelium: ut particeps eius efficiar.
verses.english: I do it all for the sake of the gospel, that I may share with it.

verses.latin: Nescitis quod ii qui in stadio currunt, omnes quidem currunt, sed unus accipit bravium? Sic currite ut comprehendatis.
verses.english: Do you not know that in a race all the runners run, but only one receives the prize? So run that you may obtain it.

verses.latin: Omnis autem qui in agone contendit, ab omnibus se abstinet: et illi quidem ut coronam corruptibilem accipiant: nos autem incorruptibilem.
verses.english: Every athlete exercises self-control in all things. They do it to receive a perishable wreath, but we an imperishable.

verses.latin: Ego igitur sic curro, non quasi incertum: sic pugno, non quasi aerem verberans:
verses.english: So I do not run aimlessly; I do not box as one beating the air.

verses.latin: sed castigo corpus meum, et in servitutem redigo: ne forte cum aliis praedicaverim, ipse reprobus efficiar.
verses.english: But I discipline my body and keep it under control, lest after preaching to others I myself should be disqualified.

verses.latin: Nolo autem vos ignorare, fratres, quoniam patres nostri omnes sub nube fuerunt, et omnes mare transierunt,
verses.english: And so, my brothers, I do not want you to be unaware that all our fathers were under the protection of the cloud, and all crossed through the sea,

verses.latin: et omnes in Moyse baptizati sunt in nube, et in mari:
verses.english: and all were baptized into Moses in the cloud and in the sea:

verses.latin: et omnes eandem escam spiritalem manducaverunt,
verses.english: and all ate the same spiritual food,

verses.latin: et omnes eundem potum spiritalem biberunt: bibebant autem de spiritali, quae sequebatur eos, petra: petra autem erat Christus.
verses.english: and all drank the same spiritual drink. They drank from the spiritual rock that followed them, and that rock was Christ.

verses.latin: Sed non in pluribus eorum bene placuit Deo: nam prostrati sunt in deserto.
verses.english: But in many of them, God was not pleased; for they were struck down in the desert.

verses.latin: Haec autem figurae nostrae factae sunt, ut non simus desideratores malorum, sicut et illi concupierunt.
verses.english: These things happened as examples for us, so that we would not be eager for evil things, as they desired them.

verses.latin: Neque idololatrae efficiamini, sicut quidam ex ipsis: quemadmodum scriptum est: Sedit populus manducare et bibere, et surrexerunt ludere.
verses.english: Do not become idolaters, as some of them did, as it is written: “The people sat down to eat and drink, and they rose up to play.”

verses.latin: Neque fornicemur, sicut quidam ex ipsis fornicati sunt, et ceciderunt una die viginti tria milia.
verses.english: Nor should we engage in sexual immorality, as some of them did, and twenty-three thousand fell in one day.

verses.latin: Neque tentemus Christum, sicut quidam eorum tentaverunt, et a serpentibus perierunt.
verses.english: Nor let us tempt Christ, as some of them tempted, and perished by serpents.

verses.latin: Neque murmuraveritis, sicut quidam eorum murmuraverunt, et perierunt a percussore.
verses.english: Nor should you grumble, as some of them grumbled, and perished by the destroyer.

verses.latin: Haec autem omnia in figura contingebant illis: scripta sunt autem ad correptionem nostram, in quos fines saeculorum pervenerunt.
verses.english: These things happened to them as examples, and they were written for our correction, upon whom the ends of the ages have come.

verses.latin: Itaque, qui se existimat stare, videat ne cadat.
verses.english: Therefore, let whoever thinks he stands, take heed that he does not fall.

verses.latin: Tentatio vos non apprehendat, nisi humana: fidelis autem Deus est: qui non sinet vos tentari supra id quod potestis, sed faciet etiam cum tentatione proventum, ut possitis sustinere.
verses.english: No temptation has overtaken you that is not common to man. But God is faithful, who will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear, but with the temptation will also make a way out, that you may be able to endure it.

verses.latin: Ideo, carissimi mei, fugite ab idolis.
verses.english: Therefore, my beloved ones, flee from idolatry.

verses.latin: Ut prudentibus loquor: judicate vos ipsi quod dico.
verses.english: I speak as to the wise: judge for yourselves what I say.

verses.latin: Calix benedictionis, cui benedicimus, nonne communicatio sanguinis Christi est? Et panis, quem frangimus, nonne participatio corporis Christi est?
verses.english: The cup of blessing which we bless, is it not the communion of the blood of Christ? The bread which we break, is it not the participation of the body of Christ?

verses.latin: Quoniam unus panis, unum corpus multi sumus, omnes qui de uno pane participamus.
verses.english: Because there is one bread, we who are many are one body, for we all partake of the one bread.

verses.latin: Videte Israhel secundum carnem: nonne qui edunt hostias, participes sunt altaris?
verses.english: Consider Israel according to the flesh: are not those who eat of the sacrifices partakers of the altar?

verses.latin: Quid ergo dico? Quod idolis immolatum sit aliquid? Aut quod idolum sit aliquid?
verses.english: What do I say then? That an idol is anything, or that which is sacrificed to idols is anything?

verses.latin: Immo quod ea quae immolant gentes, daemoniis immolant, et non Deo. Nolo vos socios fieri daemoniorum.
verses.english: No, but that the things which the Gentiles sacrifice they sacrifice to demons and not to God. I do not want you to become partners with demons.

verses.latin: Non potestis calicem Domini bibere, et calicem daemoniorum: non potestis mensae Domini participes esse, et mensae daemoniorum.
verses.english: You cannot drink the cup of the Lord and the cup of demons; you cannot partake of the table of the Lord and the table of demons.

verses.latin: An provocamus Dominum? Numquid fortiores illo sumus?
verses.english: Or do we provoke the Lord to jealousy? Are we stronger than He?

verses.latin: Omnia licent, sed non omnia expediunt: omnia licent, sed non omnia aedificant.
verses.english: “All things are lawful,” but not all things are helpful. “All things are lawful,” but not all things edify.

verses.latin: Nemo quod suum est quaerat, sed quod alterius.
verses.english: Let no one seek his own, but that of another.

verses.latin: Omne, quod in macello venit, manducate, nihil interrogantes propter conscientiam.
verses.english: Eat anything that is sold in the meat market, asking no questions for conscience’ sake.

verses.latin: Domini est terra, et plenitudo ejus.
verses.english: “The earth is the Lord’s, and all its fullness.”

verses.latin: Si quis autem ex infidelibus vocat vos, et vultis ire, omne, quod vobis apponitur, manducate, nihil interrogantes propter conscientiam.
verses.english: If any of the unbelievers invites you, and you wish to go, eat whatever is set before you, asking no question for conscience’ sake.

verses.latin: Quod si quis dixerit: Hoc immolatum est idolis, nolite manducare propter illum qui indicavit, et propter conscientiam.
verses.english: But if anyone says to you, “This was offered to idols,” do not eat it for the sake of the one who informed you, and for conscience’ sake.

verses.latin: Conscientiam autem dico, non tuam, sed alterius. Ut quid enim judicatur libertas mea ab alia conscientia?
verses.english: I mean conscience, not your own, but the other person’s; for why is my freedom judged by another’s conscience?

verses.latin: Si ego cum gratia participo, quid blasphemor pro eo quod gratias ago?
verses.english: If I partake with thanks, why am I blasphemed for that for which I give thanks?

verses.latin: Sive ergo manducatis, sive bibitis, sive aliud quid facitis, omnia in gloriam Dei facite.
verses.english: So then, whether you eat or drink, or whatever you do, do all to the glory of God.

verses.latin: Sine offensione estote Judaeis, et gentibus, et ecclesiae Dei:
verses.english: Give no offense to Jews or to Greeks or to the church of God,

verses.latin: sicut et ego per omnia omnibus placeo, non quaerens quod mihi utile est, sed quod multis, ut salvi fiant.
verses.english: just as I also please all men in everything, not seeking my own profit, but the profit of many, that they may be saved.

verses.latin: Imitator mei estote, sicut et ego Christi.
verses.english: Imitate me, even as I imitate Christ.

verses.latin: Laudo autem vos fratres, quod per omnia mei memores estis: et sicut tradidi vobis, præcepta tenetis.
verses.english: I commend you, brothers, for always remembering me and for keeping the teachings that I handed down to you.

verses.latin: Volo autem vos scire quod omnis viri caput, Christus est: caput autem mulieris, vir: caput vero Christi, Deus.
verses.english: I want you to understand this: every man has Christ as his head, a woman has a man as her head, and Christ has God as His head.

verses.latin: Omnis vir orans vel prophetans, velato capite, contumeliam facit capiti suo.
verses.english: Any man who prays or prophesies with his head covered dishonors his head.

verses.latin: Omnis vero mulier orans vel prophetans non velato capite, contumeliam facit capiti suo: unum enim est ac si rasa esset.
verses.english: And any woman who prays or prophesies with her head uncovered dishonors her head, because it is as though she had her head shaved.

verses.latin: Nam si mulier non velatur, tondetur. Si vero turpe est mulieri tondere se, aut rasam habere, velata sit.
verses.english: For if a woman does not cover her head, she should have her hair cut off. But if it is shameful for a woman to cut off her hair or shave her head, then she should cover it.

verses.latin: Vir quidem non debet velare caput: quoniam imago et gloria Dei est: mulier autem gloria viri est.
verses.english: A man, since he is the image and glory of God, shouldn't have his head covered. But woman is the glory of man.

verses.latin: Non enim vir ex muliere est, sed mulier ex viro.
verses.english: For man wasn't created from woman, but woman from man.

verses.latin: Nam et non est creatus vir propter mulierem, sed mulier propter virum.
verses.english: Man wasn't created for the sake of woman, but woman for the sake of man.

verses.latin: Ideo debet mulier potestatem habere supra caput propter angelos.
verses.english: That is why a woman should have a sign of authority on her head, because of the angels.

verses.latin: Verumtamen neque vir sine muliere, neque mulier sine viro, in Domino.
verses.english: Nevertheless, neither is woman independent of man in the Lord, nor is man independent of woman.

verses.latin: Nam sicut mulier de viro, ita et vir per mulierem: sed omnia de Deo.
verses.english: For just as woman came from man, so also man is born of woman. But all things are from God.

verses.latin: Judicate in vobismetipsis: decet mulierem, non velatam, orare Deum?
verses.english: Judge for yourselves: is it proper for a woman to pray to God with her head uncovered?

verses.latin: An ipsa natura docet vos quod vir quidem si comam nutriat, ignominia est illi:
verses.english: Doesn't nature itself teach you that if a man has long hair, it is a dishonor to him,

verses.latin: mulier vero si comam nutriat, gloria est illi: quoniam capilli pro velamine ei dati sunt?
verses.english: but if a woman has long hair, it is her glory? For her hair has been given to her for a covering.

verses.latin: Si quis autem videtur contentiosus esse: nos talem consuetudinem non habemus, neque ecclesia Dei.
verses.english: But if anyone seems to be contentious, we have no such practice, nor do the churches of God.

verses.latin: Hoc autem præcipio, non laudans quod non melius, sed in deterius convenitis.
verses.english: But in the following instructions, I do not praise you, because you come together not for the better, but for the worse.

verses.latin: Primum quidem convenientibus vobis in ecclesiam, audio scissuras esse inter vos: et ex parte credo.
verses.english: For first of all, when you come together in church, I hear that there are divisions among you, and in part I believe it.

verses.latin: Nam oportet et hæreses esse, ut et qui probati sunt, manifesti fiant in vobis.
verses.english: For there must be factions among you, so that those who are approved may be evident among you.

verses.latin: Convenientibus ergo vobis in unum, non est dominicam cœnam manducare.
verses.english: So then, when you meet together, it is not really to eat the Lord's Supper.

verses.latin: Unusquisque enim suam cœnam præsumit ad manducandum. Et alius quidem esurit, alius autem ebrius est.
verses.english: For in eating, each one goes ahead with his own supper, and one person is hungry while another is drunk.

verses.latin: Numquid domos non habetis ad manducandum et bibendum? An ecclesiam Dei contemnitis, et confunditis eos qui non habent? Quid dicam vobis? Laudo vos in hoc? Non laudo.
verses.english: Do you not have houses to eat and drink in? Or do you despise the church of God, and shame those who have nothing? What shall I say to you? Shall I praise you in this? I do not praise you.

verses.latin: Ego enim accepi a Domino quod et tradidi vobis: quoniam Dominus Jesus, in qua nocte tradebatur, accepit panem,
verses.english: For I received from the Lord what I also handed down to you: that the Lord Jesus, on the night when He was betrayed, took bread,

verses.latin: et gratias agens, fregit, et dixit: Accipite et comedite: hoc est corpus meum, quod pro vobis datur: hoc facite in meam commemorationem.
verses.english: and when He had given thanks, He broke it, and said, “Take, eat; this is My body, which is broken for you; do this in remembrance of Me.”

verses.latin: Similiter et calicem, postquam cœnavit, dicens: Hic calix novum testamentum est in meo sanguine: hoc facite quotiescumque bibetis, in meam commemorationem.
verses.english: In the same way He also took the cup after supper, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in My blood; do this, as often as you drink it, in remembrance of Me.”

verses.latin: Quotiescumque enim manducabitis panem hunc, et calicem bibetis, mortem Domini annuntiabitis donec veniat.
verses.english: For as often as you eat this bread and drink the cup, you proclaim the Lord’s death until He comes.

verses.latin: Itaque quicumque manducaverit panem hunc, vel biberit calicem Domini indigne, reus erit corporis et sanguinis Domini.
verses.english: Therefore whoever eats the bread or drinks the cup of the Lord in an unworthy manner, shall be guilty of the body and the blood of the Lord.

verses.latin: Probet autem seipsum homo: et sic de pane illo edat, et de calice bibat.
verses.english: But a man must examine himself, and so eat of the bread and drink of the cup.

verses.latin: Qui enim manducat et bibit indigne, judicium sibi manducat et bibit: non judicans corpus Domini.
verses.english: For anyone who eats and drinks without discerning the body, eats and drinks judgment on himself.

verses.latin: Ideo inter vos multi infirmi et imbecilles, et dormiunt multi.
verses.english: For this reason many among you are weak and sick, and a number are dying.

verses.latin: Quod si nosmetipsos dijudicaremus, non utique judicaremur.
verses.english: But if we judged ourselves rightly, we would not be judged.

verses.latin: Dum judicamur autem, a Domino corripimur: ut non cum hoc mundo damnemur.
verses.english: But when we are judged, we are disciplined by the Lord so that we will not be condemned with the world.

verses.latin: Itaque fratres mei, cum convenitis ad manducandum, invicem expectate.
verses.english: So then, my brothers, when you come together to eat, wait for one another.

verses.latin: Si quis esurit, domi manducet: ut non in judicium conveniatis. Cetera autem cum venero, disponam.
verses.english: If anyone is hungry, let him eat at home, so that you will not come together for judgment. And the remaining matters I will arrange when I come.

verses.latin: De spiritualibus autem, fratres, nolo vos ignorare.
verses.english: Regarding spiritual gifts, brothers, I do not want you to be ignorant.

verses.latin: Scitis quod cum gentes eratis, ad idola discurrentes, muti, prout ducebamini.
verses.english: You know that when you were Gentiles, you were being led astray, running to idols, which cannot speak, as you were led.

verses.latin: Ideo notum vobis facio quod nemo in Spiritu Dei loquens, dicit: Anathema Jesu. Et nemo potest dicere Dominus Jesus, nisi in Spiritu Sancto.
verses.english: Therefore, I make it known to you that no one speaking by the Spirit of God says: “Jesus is accursed.” And no one can say “Lord Jesus” except in the Holy Spirit.

verses.latin: Divisiones vero donorum sunt, sed idem Spiritus.
verses.english: Now there are varieties of gifts, but the same Spirit.

verses.latin: Et divisiones ministrationum sunt, et idem Dominus.
verses.english: And there are varieties of ministries, and the same Lord.

verses.latin: Et divisiones operationum sunt, sed idem Deus, qui operatur omnia in omnibus.
verses.english: And there are varieties of workings, but it is the same God who works all things in all.

verses.latin: Unicuique autem datur manifestatio Spiritus ad utilitatem.
verses.english: To each one is given the manifestation of the Spirit for profit.

verses.latin: Alii enim per Spiritum datur sermo sapientiæ: alii autem sermo scientiæ secundum eundem Spiritum:
verses.english: For to one, through the Spirit, is given the word of wisdom; to another, the word of knowledge, according to the same Spirit:

verses.latin: alteri fides in eodem Spiritu: alii gratia sanitatum in uno Spiritu:
verses.english: to another, faith in the same Spirit; to another, the grace of healings in the one Spirit:

verses.latin: alii operatio virtutum: alii prophetia: alii discretio spirituum: alii genera linguarum: alii interpretatio sermonum.
verses.english: to another, the working of miracles; to another, prophecy; to another, the discernment of spirits; to another, various kinds of tongues; to another, interpretation of words.

verses.latin: Hæc autem omnia operatur unus atque idem Spiritus, dividens singulis prout vult.
verses.english: But all these things are worked by one and the same Spirit, distributing to each one individually as He wills.

verses.latin: Nam sicut corpus unum est, et membra habet multa: omnia autem membra corporis cum sint multa, unum sunt corpus: ita et Christus.
verses.english: For as the body is one and has many members, but all the members of the body, though many, are one body, so also is Christ.

verses.latin: Etenim in uno Spiritu omnes nos in unum corpus baptizati sumus, sive Judæi, sive gentiles, sive servi, sive liberi: et omnes unum Spiritum potati sumus.
verses.english: For in one Spirit we were all baptized into one body, whether Jews or Gentiles, whether slaves or free; and we were all given to drink of one Spirit.

verses.latin: Nam et corpus non est unum membrum, sed multa.
verses.english: For the body is not one member, but many.

verses.latin: Si dixerit pes: Quoniam non sum manus, non sum de corpore: ideo non est de corpore?
verses.english: If the foot should say, “Because I am not a hand, I am not of the body,” it is not therefore not of the body?

verses.latin: Et si dixerit auris: Quoniam non sum oculus, non sum de corpore: ideo non est de corpore?
verses.english: And if the ear should say, “Because I am not an eye, I am not of the body,” it is not therefore not of the body?

verses.latin: Si totum corpus oculus, ubi auditus? Si totum auditus, ubi odoratus?
verses.english: If the whole body were an eye, where would the hearing be? If the whole were hearing, where would the smelling be?

verses.latin: Nunc autem posuit Deus membra, unumquodque eorum in corpore, sicut voluit.
verses.english: But now God has placed the members, each one of them, in the body, as He willed.

verses.latin: Quod si essent omnia unum membrum, ubi corpus?
verses.english: If all were one member, where would the body be?

verses.latin: Nunc autem multa quidem membra, unum autem corpus.
verses.english: Now indeed there are many members, but one body.

verses.latin: Non potest dicere oculus manui: Opera mea tibi necessaria sunt: aut iterum caput pedibus: Non estis mihi necessarii.
verses.english: The eye cannot say to the hand, “I have no need of you,” or again the head to the feet, “I have no need of you.”

verses.latin: Sed multo magis, quæ videntur membra corporis infirmiora esse, necessariora sunt:
verses.english: Rather, those members of the body which seem to be weaker are more necessary.

verses.latin: et quæ putamus ignobiliora membra esse corporis, his honorem abundantiorem circumdamus: et quæ inhonesta sunt nostra, abundantiorem honestatem habent.
verses.english: And those members of the body that we think to be less honorable, these we surround with greater honor; and those parts that are unpresentable, we have the greater honor.

verses.latin: At vero, nostræ honesta, nullius egent: sed Deus temperavit corpus, ei qui deficiebat, abundantiorem tribuens honorem:
verses.english: But the parts that are honorable have no need. But God has tempered the body together, giving greater honor to the one which lacked honor,

verses.latin: ut non sit schisma in corpore: sed idipsum invicem pro se sollicita sint membra.
verses.english: so that there would be no division in the body, but that the members would have the same care for one another.

verses.latin: Et si quid patitur unum membrum, compatiuntur omnia membra: sive gloriatur unum membrum, congaudent omnia membra.
verses.english: And if one member suffers, all the members suffer with it; or if one member is honored, all the members rejoice with it.

verses.latin: Vos autem estis corpus Christi, et membra de membro.
verses.english: Now you are the body of Christ, and members of His body.

verses.latin: Et quosdam posuit Deus in Ecclesia, primum apostolos, deinde prophetas, tertio doctores: deinde virtutes, exinde gratias curationum, opitulationes, gubernationes, genera linguarum.
verses.english: And God has appointed in the Church, first apostles, second prophets, third teachers; then miracles, then gifts of healings, helps, administrations, various kinds of tongues.

verses.latin: Numquid omnes apostoli? numquid omnes prophetæ? numquid omnes doctores? numquid omnes virtutes operantur?
verses.english: Are all apostles? Are all prophets? Are all teachers? Do all work miracles?

verses.latin: numquid omnes gratiam habent curationum? numquid omnes linguis loquuntur? numquid omnes interpretantur?
verses.english: Do all have gifts of healings? Do all speak in tongues? Do all interpret?

verses.latin: Amulate autem charismata majora. Et adhuc excellentiorem viam vobis demonstro.
verses.english: But earnestly desire the greater gifts. And I show you a still more excellent way.

verses.latin: Si linguis hominum loquar, et angelorum, caritatem autem non habeam, factus sum velut aes sonans, aut cymbalum tinniens.
verses.english: If I speak in the tongues of men, or even of angels, but do not have love, then I have become like a noisy gong, or a clanging cymbal.

verses.latin: Et si habuero prophetiam, et noverim mysteria omnia, et omnem scientiam, et si habuero omnem fidem ita ut montes transferam, caritatem autem non habeam, nihil sum.
verses.english: And if I have the gift of prophecy, and know all mysteries, and all knowledge, and if I have all faith, so as to move mountains, but do not have love, then I am nothing.

verses.latin: Et si distribuero in cibos pauperes omnes facultates meas, et si tradidero corpus meum ita ut ardeam, caritatem autem non habeam, nihil mihi prodest.
verses.english: And if I give away all my possessions to feed the poor, and if I deliver my body to be burned, but do not have love, it profits me nothing.

verses.latin: Caritas patiens est, benigna est; caritas non aemulatur, non agit perperam, non inflatur,
verses.english: Love endures with patience, and is kind. Love does not envy, does not parade itself, is not puffed up,

verses.latin: non est ambitiosa, non quaerit quae sua sunt, non irritatur, non cogitat malum,
verses.english: is not ambitious, does not seek its own, is not provoked to anger, and does not think evil,

verses.latin: non gaudet super iniquitate, congaudet autem veritati;
verses.english: does not rejoice in iniquity, but rejoices with the truth.

verses.latin: omnia suffert, omnia credit, omnia sperat, omnia sustinet.
verses.english: It bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, endures all things.

verses.latin: Caritas numquam excidit: sive prophetiae, vocabuntur; sive linguae, cessabunt; sive scientia, destruetur.
verses.english: Love never fails. But whether there are prophecies, they will be done away; whether there are tongues, they will cease; or whether there is knowledge, it will be destroyed.

verses.latin: Ex parte enim cognoscimus, et ex parte prophetamus.
verses.english: For we know in part, and we prophesy in part.

verses.latin: Cum autem venerit quod perfectum est, evacuabitur quod ex parte est.
verses.english: But when that which is perfect comes, then that which is in part will be done away.

verses.latin: Quando eram parvulus, loquebar ut parvulus, cogitabam ut parvulus, ratiocinabar ut parvulus: quando autem factus sum vir, evacuavi quae erant parvuli.
verses.english: When I was a child, I spoke as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child. But when I became a man, I put away childish things.

verses.latin: Videmus nunc per speculum in aenigmate: tunc autem facie ad faciem. Nunc cognosco ex parte: tunc autem cognoscam sicut et cognitus sum.
verses.english: For now we see through a glass in a dark manner, but then we will see face to face. Now I know in part; but then I will know as I also am known.

verses.latin: Nunc autem manent fides, spes, caritas, tria haec: major autem horum est caritas.
verses.english: And now these three remain: faith, hope, and love. But the greatest of these is love.

verses.latin: Sectamini charitatem: æmulamini autem spiritualia: magis autem ut prophetetis.
verses.english: Pursue love. Be eager for the gifts of the Spirit, especially the gift of prophecy.

verses.latin: Qui enim loquitur lingua, non hominibus loquitur, sed Deo: nemo enim audit: spiritu autem loquitur mysteria.
verses.english: Anyone who speaks in a language that no one understands is speaking to God, not to people. No one understands him. He is speaking mysteries in the Spirit.

verses.latin: Qui autem prophetat, hominibus loquitur ædificationem, et consolationem, et exhortationem.
verses.english: But the one who prophesies speaks to people, to build them up, encourage them, and comfort them.

verses.latin: Qui loquitur lingua, semetipsum ædificat: qui autem prophetat, ecclesiam Dei ædificat.
verses.english: Anyone who speaks in a language that no one understands builds up himself. But the one who prophesies builds up the Church of God.

verses.latin: Volo autem vos omnes loqui linguis, magis autem prophetare. Major est enim qui prophetat, quam qui loquitur linguis: nisi forte interpretetur, ut ecclesia ædificationem accipiat.
verses.english: I wish all of you spoke in languages, but even more that you prophesied. The one who prophesies is greater than the one who speaks in languages, unless he interprets, so that the Church may be built up.

verses.latin: Nunc autem, fratres, si venero ad vos loquens linguis, quid vobis prodero, nisi vobis loquar aut in revelatione, aut in scientia, aut in prophetia, aut in doctrina?
verses.english: Now, brothers and sisters, if I come to you speaking in languages, how will I help you unless I speak to you in a revelation, or in knowledge, or in prophecy, or in teaching?

verses.latin: Etenim sine anima, voces dabuntur, aut tibiis, aut citharis, nisi distinctionem sonituum dederint, quomodo scietur quod canitur aut quod psallitur?
verses.english: Even lifeless instruments, such as the flute or the harp, must give a clear sound if they are to be understood. How will anyone know what is being played?

verses.latin: Etenim si tuba incertam vocem dederit, quis præparabit se ad bellum?
verses.english: If the trumpet gives an unclear sound, who will prepare for battle?

verses.latin: Ita et vos per linguam, nisi manifestum sermonem dederitis, quomodo scietur id quod dicitur? eritis enim in aërem loquentes.
verses.english: So it is with you. Unless you speak intelligible words with your tongue, how will anyone know what you are saying? You will be speaking into the air.

verses.latin: Tot genera linguarum, fortasse, sunt in hoc mundo: et nihil sine voce est.
verses.english: There are perhaps many kinds of languages in the world, and none is without meaning.

verses.latin: Si igitur nesciero virtutem vocis, ero ei, cui loquor, barbarus: et qui loquitur mihi, barbarus ero.
verses.english: If I do not understand the meaning of the language, I will be a foreigner to the speaker, and the speaker a foreigner to me.

verses.latin: Ita et vos, quoniam æmulatores estis spirituum, ad ædificationem ecclesiæ quærite abundare.
verses.english: So it is with you. Since you are eager for gifts of the Spirit, seek to abound in them for the building up of the Church.

verses.latin: Ideo qui loquitur lingua, oret ut interpretetur.
